items.message:
River levels are rising at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected from this evening, 03/12/23.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until later this week.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 04/12/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull

items.message:
The Lower River Hull flood alert has been issued.
Areas near the watercourse at Cottingham Station Road are most at risk. No property flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 04/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but are steadily falling on the River Churn following previous heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Cerney Wick area. The weather forecast today, 03/12/23, is for some rain through the day and a band of heavy rain overnight tonight into Monday morning. We expect river levels to remain high and responsive to rainfall over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 3/12/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
River levels are steady and are forecast to rise on the Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream due to rainfall.
Areas most at risk include the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries..
Flooding is possible at the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries. from 11:30 PM on 03/12/2023.
Further rainfall is forecast overnight.
River levels will rise steadily at the Allerford, Beggearn Huish, Parsons Street, Sampford Brett, Swill Bridge, West Luccombe, Williton gauge.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 03:00 PM on 04/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Butts Bridge river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible in the early hours of tomorrow morning, 04/12/23. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.  Further rainfall is forecast overnight. We expect river levels to remain high for most of tomorrow, 04/12/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

We expect river levels to remain high and responsive to rainfall over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Sunday 3rd December and for the next few days. Water levels continue to remain high in this area.  This is due to a natural tide locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning.   We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Monday 4th December, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle due to rainfall this evening and overnight. Areas most at risk include the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.
Flooding is possible at the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. from 10:00 PM on 03/12/2023.
River levels will rise steadily in response to the rainfall.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Plan driving routes to avoid road Deep Ford Lane in Chetnole which are affected by flooding and to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 03:00 PM on 04/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels remain high but steady on the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon due to groundwater.  

Areas most at risk include tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.

Further rainfall is forecast for Sunday and into Monday and we will be monitoring the situation.

No further flooding to fields and roads is expected at the moment but there may still be standing water seen for several days.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 04/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Willington and Shardlow river gauges as a result of persistent heavy rainfall and some snow melt.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin from tomorrow morning, 04/12/23.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 36 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until 06/12/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message: Groundwater levels have responded to rainfall over the past few weeks and remain high at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming weeks.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 6.87 m and is generally falling. The drain level is 6.97 m and is falling slowly.
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.30 m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86 m, and the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93 m.
There are showers forecast for today with persistent rain overnight on Sunday 3/12/2023. The River Yeo is currently falling slowly. The level  occasionally fluctuates in response to pumping changes in the river system.  The river level may rise following rainfall.
We continue to pump to evacuate water from the Moors but if river levels rise this may reduce our ability to pump.
We are monitoring the situation and continue to check the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens.
Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on local road closures.
For water levels on the rivers, please refer to our website: (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels).
This message will be updated by 15:00 on Monday 4/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: In Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle, groundwater levels are high and rising slowly. Since Friday 24/11/2023, 22mm of rain has been recorded at Walderton. The groundwater level at our borehole in Finchdean has risen by 1.06m in that time. The Idsworth Lavant is now flowing through all villages. Pumps used to reduce water levels will be required for a small number of properties in Finchdean and surface water could flood property during heavier rain events. From today 30/11/2023 until Saturday 02/12/2023, only very small amounts of rain are forecast. On Sunday 03/12/2023 and Monday 04/12/2023, up to 20mm per day is forecast in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects the area then groundwater will continue to rise and more properties could be affected. If not, then groundwater levels are expected to peak in the next couple of days. We are liaising with the Flood Action Group. If you use pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure they are operational. Further groundwater flooding impacts are likely this winter. This Flood Alert will be updated at 17:00 on Thursday 07/12/2023.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Trent, River Greet, Potwell Dyke, Carr Dyke, Dover Beck, Cocker Beck, Thurgarton Beck, Fairham Brook

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Lowdham Grange river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, it is possible that flooding of roads and farmland will begin between 05:00 and 06:00 tomorrow, 04/12/2023.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around the tributaries of the River Trent in Nottinghamshire, the River Greet, Potwell Dyke, Dover Beck, Cocker Beck, Woodborough Brook, Ouse Dyke, Thurgarton Beck and others.   

Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until 05:00 on 05/12/2023.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  

Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  

This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 04/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the recent rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole in Longacre in the Lambourn Valley. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected within the next few days by flooding from groundwater.

We expect levels to continue to rise over the next few weeks in response to rainfall forecast across the area. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message tomorrow, 4/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Upper Tean river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible in the early hours of tomorrow morning, 04/12/23.  Flooding may affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Churnet between Leek and Rocester and the River Tean between Adderley and Spath including Cecilly Brook at Cheadle.   
Further rainfall is forecast overnight. We expect river levels to remain high for most of tomorrow, 04/12/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Asker, River Brit, River Bride, River Char, River Lim

items.message: River levels are high and rising on the River Lim, River Char, River Winniford, Simene River, River Brit, River Asker, River Mangerton and the River Bride due to the heavy rainfall today.  Further rainfall is expected overnight with the storm that is approaching.  Flooding is forecast to affect all rivers in the West Dorset area.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this Warning if necessary.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  People in this area should consider taking action now and install any property flood resilience measures.  We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 04/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Flooding is possible from the early hours on Monday morning.
Widespread heavy rainfall is forecast overnight across Devon. This will cause rivers in the area to rise.  
The main areas of concern are Exebridge, Bolham, Bampton and Tiverton. River levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers.
We expect rivers to remain high throughout Monday. 
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated on Monday evening or earlier if the situation changes.

items.message:
Flooding is possible overnight on Sunday 3rd December and into Monday. Frontal rain will cross the area late on Sunday afternoon and into the early hours of Monday morning bringing rainfall totals of 20-30mm.
Catchments are wet following recent rainfall and river levels are expected to react quickly in response to the rainfall, which may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high through Monday, though no flooding to properties is currently forecast. 
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Monday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Devon and Smite in Leicestershire and Nottinghamshire
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Colston Bassett river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, it is possible that flooding of roads and farmland will begin between 07:00 and 08:00 tomorrow, 04/12/2023.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads along the River Smite. Church Gate and Bunnison Lane in Colston Bassett could be impassable, with potentially dangerous depths of flood water.  Areas around the River Devon could also be affected at Easthorpe, Bottesford, Belvoir Lane and the Woolsthorpe to Belvoir road in Woolsthorpe, Church Lane and Main Street in Muston.   

Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until 11:00 on 05/12/2023.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Tame between Horseley Heath and Castle Vale and the Ford Brook between Walsall and Bescot.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 04/12/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise during the early hours of Monday morning 04/12/23 at the Evesham river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected from 03:00 tomorrow, 04/12/23.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham, Twyning and the Eckington Road. Predicted peaks:- Evesham 2.5m to 2.8m, Bredon 2.5m to 2.8m monday overnight into Tuesday 05/12/23   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Tuesday 05/12/23
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 09:00 on 04/12/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise during the early hours of Monday morning 04/12/23 at the Besford Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 03:00 tomorrow, 04/12/23.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Brooks from Webheath to Defford. Other locations that may be affected include Crowle, Wickenham, Peopleton, Pinvin and Pershore. Local fords may also be flooded.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Tuesday 05/12/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 09:00 on 04/12/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Eathorpe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible overnight and into tomorrow, 04/12/23.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington.
Further rainfall is forecast overnight.  We expect river levels to continue to rise overnight.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 04/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Loughborough urban watercourses and local tributaries to the River Soar
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Shepshed river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 2am, 04/12/23.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around the Black Brook at Shepshed, the Grace Dieu Brook, Burleigh Brook, Wood Brook, Grammar School Brook, Hermitage Brook, Sileby Brook, Long Whatton Brook, King’s Brook and Kingston Brook.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Tuesday, 05/12/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 04/12/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teme, River Onny, River Corve

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Corve river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible in the early hours of tomorrow morning, 04/12/23. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Teme, River Onny and River Corve and their tributaries. Locations that may be affected include Bishops Castle, Church Stretton, Knighton and Ludlow. Predicted peaks:-  Leintwardine 1.2m to 1.3m Tuesday afternoon, 05/12/23,  Onibury 2.2m to 2.5m Monday afternoon 04/12/23; Corve 3.5m to 3.8m Tuesday morning 05/12/23.. items.description: Upper River Mole, Ifield Brook, Gatwick Stream and Burstow Stream
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ifield Brook, River Mole, Gatwick Stream, Burstow Stream

items.message: River levels are forecast to rise on the River Mole due to rainfall overnight Sunday to Monday. Flooding is forecast to affect low lying land near the River Mole, Ifield Brook, River Mole, Gatwick Stream and Burstow Stream. Flooding of low-lying land is possible at Horley from 07:00 AM on 04/12/2023. Property flooding is not expected at this time. Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow afternoon and evening. River levels are forecast to rise again tomorrow evening. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 04/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cole, Dorcan Brook and South Marston Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
This Flood Alert has been issued in advance of a band of rain, which could be heavy at times, moving across south west England overnight tonight 03/12/23. If the highest forecast rainfall totals occur in the Swindon area we would expect water levels on the River Cole and Dorcan Brook to rise. We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 04/12/23, or as the situation changes.
